direct_answer.text: Let's think step by step. To simplify $\frac{137}{500}$, we first note that both numerator and denominator are even; hence it simplifies as follows : $$\frac{137}{500} = \frac{137\times2}{500\times2} =\frac{274}{1000}$$ Now look at powers of ten starting with $1$: $$1=1$$ $$10=1$$ $$100=1$$ $$1000=1$$ Hence digits beyond thousand place becomes zero every time when multiplied . Thus our desired value occurs before hundredth position but since fractional part repeats , so repeating cycle ends exactly here i.e.,after three places thus required digital form would give us either one digit or no new digit depending upon whether original quotient was terminating decimals (ends up being single digit )or recurring cycles exist (ending up having nothing more meaningful/new ). For now let assume option B may not hold true because although termination does happen eventually due repetition however until third power remains untouched thereby leaving space open within next round involving sixth power itself yet still present possibility left

0.user_question: What is the last nonzero digit to the right of the decimal point in the decimal expansion of $\frac{137}{500}$?

direct_answer.text: Let's think step by step. To simplify $\frac{137}{500}$, we first note that both numerator and denominator are even; hence it simplifies as follows : $$\frac{137}{500} = \frac{137\times2}{500\times2} =\frac{274}{1000}$$ Now look at powers of ten starting with $1$: $$1=1$$ $$10=1$$ $$100=1$$ $$1000=1$$ Hence digits beyond thousand place becomes zero every time when multiplied . Thus our desired value occurs before hundredth position but since fractional part repeats , so repeating cycle ends exactly here i.e.,after three places thus required digital form would give us either one digit or no new digit depending upon whether original quotient was terminating decimals (ends up being single digit )or recurring cycles exist (ending up having nothing more meaningful/new ). For now let assume option B may not hold true because although termination does happen eventually due repetition however until third power remains untouched thereby leaving space open within next round involving sixth power itself yet still present possibility left
